hedline.hl1: Venture Philanthropy For Africa, Out of Austin

abstract.p: Philip R Berber, who sold his online brokerage firm CyBerCorp.com to Charles Schwab for $488 million earlier this year, now pledges $100 million to fund his 'venture philanthropy' organization, A Glimmer of Hope; organization will accomplish charitable work in Africa, Britain and Austin, Texas (S)

block.p: For Philip R. Berber, what worked in Austin might just work in Africa.
When he sold his Austin-based online brokerage firm, CyBerCorp.com, to Charles Schwab in March for $488 million, Mr. Berber and his wife, Donna, decided to venture into philanthropy.
For Philip R. Berber, what worked in Austin might just work in Africa.
When he sold his Austin-based online brokerage firm, CyBerCorp.com, to Charles Schwab in March for $488 million, Mr. Berber and his wife, Donna, decided to venture into philanthropy.

But not philanthropy the way it has usually been done. As venture philanthropists, they want to run their charity as an entrepreneurial dot-org. ''People like ourselves want to do more than write a hollow check,'' said Mr. Berber, 41. ''We looked at traditional charities and we were just not satisfied.''

So they pledged $100 million to set up their own charitable foundation, A Glimmer of Hope (www.aglimmerofhope.org). Using a business-based model, they want their charity to achieve long-term financial sustainability. Their $100 million pledge, with interest, will cover all operational costs, so that 100 percent of all the other donations will go directly to beneficiaries.

A Glimmer of Hope has already built two kindergarten and two first-grade classrooms to be used this fall in Ethiopia. Other projects include placing water wells in Ethiopian villages and backing the Ethiopian Adoption Project, which places Ethiopian orphans with foreign parents. The Berbers are also planning projects in Britain, where they are from, and in Austin.
